titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by James A. Kohler, Project Archivist

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-01-11T08:49-0500

physdesc.extent: (1 records carton, 1 Hollinger box, 3 half Hollinger boxes, 1 shared flat file drawer, tube)

did.abstract: The Alan Freed Collection spans the years 1918 to 1992, with the bulk of the collection dating between 1954 and 1964. The collection consists primarily of financial and court documents relating to the commercial bribery case brought by the City of New York against Alan Freed, known as "Payola." These files contain accounting records, Assistant District Attorney notes, cancelled checks, contracts, correspondence, indictments, invoices, memoranda, music clearance sheets, reports, State of New York Grand Jury exhibits, subpoenas, witness statements and summaries, as well as many duplicate and annotated photocopies of documents. Other materials in the collection relate to Freed’s renowned career as a radio, television, and film personality and include lobby cards, magazine articles, movie posters, programs, an audio and video recording, sheet music, and yearbooks. The collection as a whole illustrates Freed's impact on the early history of rock and roll. Seen in a broader context, the collection provides insights to the recording and broadcasting industries in the 1950s and early 1960s, the resulting “Payola” scandal, and its long-lasting effects.
did.langmaterial: Collection is primarily in English; materials in French and Spanish are indicated at the item level.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Patrons must sign the Acknowledgment of Legal Responsibility and Privacy Rights statement on the Researcher Registration form before using this collection. Series VII: 2011 Accruals is CLOSED until a signed gift agreement can be secured from the donor. Some of the materials in the collection are confidential and, therefore, are RESTRICTED. Redacted access copies of the confidential documents are available in the collection. The condition of some of the audiovisual materials in the collection has not yet been determined for playback purposes. Some of the audiovisual materials in the collection are on defunct media formats and, therefore, are RESTRICTED. Access copies of these materials may have to be created prior to use. Consult the Library and Archives staff in advance of your visit to ensure access to these materials is available.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Inc.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: The Alan Freed Collection was received by the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Foundation, Inc. as a permanent loan from Judith Fisher Freed on August 29, 2002. An accrual to the Alan Freed Collection was received by the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Inc. as a restricted gift from Judith Fisher Freed on August 30, 2011.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by James A. Kohler, Project Archivist. Completed February 2, 2011. Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS and local processing manual. Accrual added and finding aid revised by James A. Kohler, Project Archivist. Completed September 7, 2011.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

chronitem.event: Albert James Freed is born in Johnston, Pa.
The Freed family moves to Salem, Ohio.
Freed is hired for his first broadcasting job by WKST in New Castle, Pa., as host of a nightly classical music program.
Hired as a sportscaster at WKBN in Youngstown, Ohio.
Hired as a disc jockey at WAKR-AM in Akron, Ohio, playing hot jazz and pop recordings.
Hired at WXEL-TV in Cleveland, Ohio and hosts the afternoon movie.
Leo Mintz convinces him to emcee a rhythm and blues program on WJW-AM in Cleveland.
Organized with Mintz and Lew Platt, the Moondog Coronation Ball is held at the Cleveland Arena and is considered the country’s first rock and roll concert.
Hired as a disc jockey by WINS in New York, N.Y.
Promotes the first of many live shows in New York City.
Stars in Rock Around The Rock as himself, the first of five film appearances.
Hired by ABC-TV to emcee a rock and roll dance show Alan Freed’s Big Beat; show is canceled months later after controversy over performer Frankie Lymon dancing with a white teenager.

eventgrp.event: Arrested and charged with inciting a riot at a Boston, Massachusetts concert he promoted; the charges are dropped.
Hired by WABC in New York, N.Y.

chronitem.event: Fired by WABC.
Indicted for commercial bribery in the state of New York.
Hired as a disc jockey by KDAY in Los Angeles, California.
Pleads guilty to two charges of commercial bribery.
Dies of complications from alcoholism in Palm Springs, Ca.
Inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
Inducted into the Radio Hall of Fame.
Ashes are interred at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland.

bioghist.p: Alan Freed, the disc jockey who became famous for coining the term “rock and roll” to describe the rhythm and blues records he was broadcasting, began what would become a revolutionary radio career in New Castle, Pennsylvania in 1942. By 1951 Freed was in Cleveland, Ohio and working in television. Record Rendezvous owner Leo Mintz urged Freed to host a radio program featuring African-American rhythm and blues, based on the increasing number of white teenagers buying “race records” at his store. On July 11, 1951 Freed began hosting what he called the "Moondog's Rock 'n' Roll Party," with Freed himself as the "Moondog." The popularity of the program quickly grew and, by March of 1952, Freed was promoting his own Moondog Coronation Ball concert, recognized by many as the first rock and roll concert ever held. The concert was oversold and between 15,000-20,000 teenagers attempted to fill the Cleveland venue with a seating capacity of only 12,500. The concert was quickly shutdown, and Freed’s notoriety grew, leading to a job offer from WINS in New York, which was changing its programming format to rock and roll.

Once in New York, Freed’s popularity and influence continued to grow. He engaged in the common practice of accepting payments or writing credits to get air time for certain records (as Freed did for Chuck Berry’s “Maybellene”). This would become known as “payola” and was Freed’s ultimate downfall. But, at WINS from 1954-1958, Freed enjoyed a success that few disc jockeys ever achieved. He promoted live shows, was interviewed in print and on television, starred in films, and hosted a television dance show and his own radio show. Then in 1959 he was fired by WABC for refusing to sign a “practices in the selection of music for broadcast affidavit,” stating that he never accepted incentives for playing records. In early 1960, he was indicted on 26 counts of commercial bribery in the State of New York. He would ultimately plead guilty to two counts, receive a suspended sentence, and pay a $300 fine.

Freed never again enjoyed the success or influence he had in the 1950s, moving from radio station to radio station in California and Florida, and eventually died of kidney and liver failure from alcoholism. Regardless, his reputation as a pioneer in the history of radio, and rock and roll in particular, remains intact. He was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as part of its inaugural class in 1986 and into the Radio Hall of Fame in 1988. Finally in 2002, as part of an exhibit dedicated to the “Architects of Rock and Roll,” Alan Freed’s ashes were interred at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland, Ohio.

list.head: Recommended Resources
list.item: Freed, Judith Fisher. Alan Freed. Accessed October 10, 2011. http://www.alanfreed.com.
Jackson, John A. Big Beat Heat: Alan Freed and the Early Years of Rock & Roll. New York: Schirmer Books, 1991.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Alan Freed Collection, Library and Archives, Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum.

accruals.head: Accruals note
accruals.p: Accruals to the collection are located in Series VII.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Commercial recordings and publications have been transferred to the library collection. Please search for the "Alan Freed Collection" in the library catalog for a list of donated titles.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials providing content on Alan Freed may be found in the following collections in this repository: Terry Stewart Collection. Related materials may also be found in other collections that constitute a part of the Northeast Ohio Popular Music Archives.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Some of the materials in this series are confidential and, therefore, are RESTRICTED. Redacted access copies of the confidential documents are available in the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series I: Financial Records [RESTRICTED] contains documents pertaining to the employment and business dealings of Alan Freed, including accounting records, cancelled checks, contracts, correspondence, invoices, music clearance sheets, and photographs. Some of the documents in this section were also used as State of New York Grand Jury exhibits for the People v. Freed court case. Files are arranged alphabetically by company and by individual.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries I: Action Records contains one file of cancelled checks. Checks are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries II: ADC contains one file of cancelled checks. Checks are arranged chronologically with District Attorney's information for the Payola case located at the end.

did.unittitle: District Attorney’s Office envelope with Alpha checks for payment of Alan Freed's Live [Budget]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries III: ABC includes files related to accounting, advertising, contracts with local facilities, correspondence, and music clearance sheets from the Alan Freed Show. Files are in alphabetical order by title. Items in the files are arranged chronologically. Some of the items in this subseries are photocopies of original documents; some are annotated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries VII: John Brantley contains checks made payable to Brantley, who worked as Alan Freed's assistant from September 7, 1954 to November 1959. The checks are written from a number of different companies, including Alpha Distributing Company, Stamford Productions, Superior Record Sales, and W.S.F. Checks are arranged chronologically.

Series II: People v. Alan Freed

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series II: People v. Alan Freed contains documents pertaining to the City of New York’s criminal case against Alan Freed for commercial bribery, including Assistant District Attorney notes, correspondence, indictments, memoranda, reports, subpoenas, and witness statements and summaries. Files are arranged alphabetically by document type and then chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series IV: Ephemera contains materials related to Alan Freed and his live appearances and films, including advertisements, photographs, posters, press books, programs, and tickets. The materials are arranged by type and then chronologically. Oversize materials are stored out of sequence due to size and condition concerns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V: Personal Papers [RESTRICTED] contains documents pertaining to the life, employment, and death of Alan Freed, including birth and death certificates, and his pathology report. The materials are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Freed, Albert James Certification of Birth (photocopy)

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This item is confidential and is, therefore, RESTRICTED. A redacted access copy of this confidential document is available in the collection.

did.unittitle: Freed, Albert James and Betty Lou Bean marriage license (photocopy)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series VI: Audiovisual Materials contains materials related to Alan Freed and his career, including an 8-track audiocassette soundtrack from a film based on his life, and a videotape of The Big Beat with Bobby Darin as host.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Some of the audiovisual materials in this series are on defunct media formats and, therefore, are RESTRICTED. Access copies of these materials will have to be created prior to use. Consult the Library and Archives staff in advance of your visit to ensure access to these materials is available.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: An audiocassette, videocassette, various singles, and LPs have been transferred to the library collection. Please search for the "Alan Freed Collection" in the library catalog for a list of donated titles.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This audiovisual material is on a defunct media formats and, therefore, is RESTRICTED. An access copy of this materials will have to be created prior to use. Consult the Library and Archives staff in advance of your visit to ensure access to these materials is available.

did.unittitle: VHS videocassette, The Big Beat with Bobby Darin as host

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The condition of this item has not yet been determined for playback purposes. An access copy of this item may have to be created prior to use. Consult the Library and Archives staff in advance of your visit to ensure access to this item is available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII: 2011 [RESTRICTED] contains documents, magazines, and photographs pertaining to the life, employment, and death of Alan Freed, including birth and death certificates, his pathology report, high school yearbooks, and the accounting from one of his films. The materials are arranged alphabetically by type, then chronologically.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The materials in this series are CLOSED until a signed gift agreement can be secured from the donor. Some of the materials in the collection are confidential and are, therefore, RESTRICTED. Consult the Library and Archives staff in advance of your visit to ensure access to these materials is available.
